author: Madison Williams
title: Dan Campbell Makes Lions' Plan on Resting Players Moving Forward Very Clear
text:
Dan Campbell Makes Lions' Plan on Resting Players Moving Forward Very Clear
The Detroit Lions are on a roll.
Sitting atop the NFC at 13-2, a win this week against the San Francisco 49ers, paired with a Green Bay Packers win over the Minnesota Vikings, would [ensure that the Lions have the top seed in the NFC](https://www.si.com/nfl/week-17-nfl-clinching-scenarios-how-five-teams-can-punch-playoff-ticket), and the first-round bye that comes with it, before a snap of football is played in Week 18.
If the Vikings beat the Packers, then bragging rights in the NFC North and the conference will come down to next weekâ€™s game between the Lions and Vikings, and this weekâ€™s game between the Lions and 49ers will essentially be meaningless in terms of conference seeding.
Given that the Lions donâ€™t play until Monday night, and thus will know the outcome of the Packers-Vikings game before taking the field, thereâ€™s a scenario that Detroit knows their game in San Francisco does not matter, and could sit their starters. Any extra bit of rest, whether it came in Week 17 or 18, would be a boon for the Lions, as [theyâ€™ve been dealing with a slew of injuries on defense](https://www.si.com/nfl/lions-lose-three-key-defensive-players-to-brutal-injuries-in-loss-to-bills).
However, Lions coach Dan Campbell doesn't sound like he plans to rest any players this week, regardless of the outcome of the Vikings game. That's not the Lions way.
â€œIâ€™ll make this easy for everybody, that way all the critics can jump out and start attacking, but that way you donâ€™t have to debate them anymore," Campbell said Wednesday. "Weâ€™re bringing everything we got to this game and we are playing, I donâ€™t care what it looks like and where itâ€™s at and whoâ€™s this, whoâ€™s that. Weâ€™re going out to play and win this game, out on the West Coast. So there you go.â€�
Since Week 15, the Lions have lost [running back David Montgomery](https://www.si.com/nfl/lions-more-bad-news-latest-david-montgomery-injury-update), [defensive lineman Alim McNeill](https://www.si.com/nfl/lions-lose-three-key-defensive-players-to-brutal-injuries-in-loss-to-bills), cornerback Carlton Davis III and cornerback Khalil Dorsey to injuries. The Lions still managed to crush the Chicago Bears 34â€“17 last weekend.
The Lions have their first Super Bowl appearance and win on their minds, especially after they reached the NFC Championship game season. Even though they have a hurt team, [Campbell is still confident](https://www.si.com/nfl/dan-campbell-honest-admission-mindset-amid-lions-injury-issues) the Lions can make a deep run.

author: Carter Skaggs
title: Perfect North Slopes is a winter wonderland rain, snow or shine
text: ENTERTAINMENTPerfect North Slopes is a winter wonderland rain, snow or shine Carter SkaggsBen Donaldson, 38, originally of Cincinnati, shreds down the black diamond Center Stage slope on his snowboard on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerJacob Clark, 12, of Lexington, Ky., makes his way towards Perfect North Slopes’ new quad chair lift on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind. Earlier this year, the red three-person chair lift was upgraded to a four-person lift.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers barrel down the tubing slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind. A specific section of Perfect North is dedicated to tubing, where tube lovers, those who are less experienced or younger guests can enjoy the snowy slopes.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSkiers and snowboarders trek to their next slope near the main lodge on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerA snowboarder and skier speed down the black diamond Center Stage slope on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerBrysen Rose, 8, left, rests on the ground at the feet of Steven Rose, 34, both of Hebron, Ky., at the bottom of a beginner slope at Perfect North Slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerPerfect North Slopes Ski Instructor Joe Schmidt teaches a group lesson on the basics of skiing on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind. Perfect North offers self-guided, group and private lessons in skiing and snowboarding.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSkiers collect at the top of one of the beginner slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind. Perfect North has 23 runs, including multiple for tubing.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerJanice Hale, 70, left, and Riley Smith, 12, both of Elljay, Ga., gaze at snow covered slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSkiers are lifted up the tallest slope by the new quad chair lift on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerA snowboarder speeds down the black diamond Center Stage slope on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerThe Main Lodge of Perfect North Slopes offers a wide array of snacks and entrees with seating on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers of all ages trek towards an escalator that will take them to the top of the tubing slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers can link their tubes together to go down the slopes all at once on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind. A specific section of Perfect North is dedicated to tubing, where tube lovers, those who are less experienced or younger guests can enjoy the snowy slopes.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers disembark from their tubes and walk toward the exit, made of gravel, on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers advance up the escalator to the top of the tubing slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers of all ages trek towards an escalator that will take them to the top of the tubing slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerA snowboarder and skier speed down the black diamond Center Stage slope on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSkiers and snowboarders fly down the black diamond Center Stage slope in the rain on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The EnquirerSnow tubers of all ages take to the slopes on Saturday, Dec. 30, 2023, at Perfect North Slopes in Lawrenceburg, Ind.Carter Skaggs/The Enquirer

author: NBC Chicago Staff
title: Illinois star Terrence Shannon acquitted on rape charges in Kansas case
text: Former Illinois guard and current NBA Draft prospect Terrance Shannon Jr. was acquitted on all charges related to an alleged sexual assault in Kansas. Shannon was found not guilty on felony charges of rape and aggravated sexual battery in the trial, which took place this week in a Kansas courtroom. The charges stemmed from an incident in Sept. 2023, when Shannon was arrested and charged with rape. He was accused of grabbing a woman’s buttocks and reaching under her skirt, charges that his lawyers vehemently denied. Shannon testified in court that he never touched the woman. After he was charged, Shannon was suspended indefinitely, but that suspension was overturned by a federal court, allowing him to return to the Illini roster after missing six games. Illinois ultimately reached the Elite Eight and captured the Big Ten Tournament title, with Shannon playing a significant role in his final NCAA season. Shannon will likely be selected in the upcoming NBA Draft, scheduled to take place later this month in New York. Feeling out of the loop? We'll catch you up on the Chicago news you need to know. Sign up for the weekly [Chicago Catch-Up newsletter here.]

author: Louis Juricic
title: Tenon Medical annuncia il rilascio di tre brevetti statunitensi Da Investing.com
text:
Rafforza ulteriormente il portafoglio brevetti internazionale e sottolinea l'impegno dell'azienda nell'innovazione di sistemi e metodi per la stabilizzazione dell'articolazione sacroiliaca
Tenon Medical, Inc. (TNON) ("Tenon" o la "Società"), un'azienda che sta trasformando l'assistenza per i pazienti affetti da determinati disturbi dell'articolazione sacroiliaca (SIJ), ha annunciato oggi il rilascio dei brevetti statunitensi n. 12.115.075, 12.115.076 e 12.115.077.
I brevetti statunitensi n. 12.115.075 e 12.115.076, entrambi intitolati "Protesi per la stabilizzazione dell'articolazione sacroiliaca", sono relativi alle protesi Catamaran® avanzate di Tenon che includono composizioni uniche per il rilascio di farmaci, che migliorano la sigillatura delle protesi nelle strutture ossee dell'articolazione sacroiliaca e la crescita ossea intorno e all'interno delle protesi quando queste vengono impiantate nell'articolazione sacroiliaca.
Il brevetto statunitense n. 12.115.077, intitolato "Sistemi, apparecchi e metodi per la stabilizzazione delle articolazioni sacroiliache", riguarda protesi per l'articolazione sacroiliaca con strutture e configurazioni uniche per correggere la stabilizzazione fallita dell'articolazione sacroiliaca con impianti commerciali alternativi senza richiedere la rimozione dell'impianto fallito.
I tre (3) brevetti statunitensi rafforzano ulteriormente il crescente portafoglio brevetti della Società per il suo sistema di fusione dell'articolazione sacroiliaca Catamaran®, che ora comprende dodici (12) brevetti statunitensi e stranieri (internazionali) rilasciati e ventitre (23) domande di brevetto statunitensi e straniere in attesa.
"Siamo lieti del riconoscimento da parte dell'USPTO delle innovative protesi per l'articolazione sacroiliaca Catamaran® che forniranno una soluzione di prima classe per rispondere specificamente alla necessità di revisione di altri dispositivi inefficaci per l'articolazione sacroiliaca", ha commentato Richard Ginn, Co-fondatore e Chief Technology Officer di Tenon Medical. Ha concluso: "Il rilascio di questi brevetti rafforza l'attenzione di Tenon sull'innovazione e allo stesso tempo protegge la nostra piattaforma tecnologica, rafforzando la nostra posizione competitiva nel settore".
Questo articolo è stato generato e tradotto con il supporto dell'intelligenza artificiale e revisionato da un redattore. Per ulteriori informazioni, consultare i nostri T&C.

author: @BahiaNoticias
title: Acidente com moto na BR-242 deixa motociclista gravemente ferido em Barreiras
text:
Acidente com moto na BR-242 deixa motociclista gravemente ferido no oeste baiano
Por Redação
Um motociclista sofreu um grave acidente na BR-242, próximo à entrada da Vila Nova em[ Barreiras](http://bahianoticias.com.br/tags/barreiras), no Oeste da Bahia. O caso aconteceu na manhã desta quinta-feira (19). Segundo informações preliminares, a vítima, que conduzia uma Honda Biz sentido Atacadão, perdeu o controle da motocicleta após passar por cima de um tachão solto na pista.
Arremessado para a pista contrária, o motociclista foi atingido por um caminhão. Equipes do Serviço de Atendimento Móvel de Urgência (SAMU) foram acionadas e socorreram a vítima, que apresentava fratura exposta na perna direita, corte profundo no calcanhar, suspeita de fratura no braço esquerdo e lesões no ombro e tórax
Segundo informações do [Blog do Braga,](https://blogbraga.com.br/) parceiro do Bahia Notícias, após os primeiros socorros, ele foi encaminhado em estado grave para o Hospital do Oeste.
O motorista do caminhão, que não se feriu, permaneceu no local à disposição das autoridades. A Polícia Militar esteve presente para registrar a ocorrência, controlar o trânsito e iniciar as investigações sobre as causas do acidente. A motocicleta envolvida foi posteriormente removida por um familiar da vítima
topics: Disaster and Accident->transportation accident and incident

author: Dylan Mugenga,Michel Nkurunziza
title: Rwanda, Sweden sign deal to mobilise climate finance through carbon market - The New Times
text: Rwanda and Sweden, on October 3, signed an agreement to mobilise climate finance through the carbon market. The agreement, signed between the Ministry of Environment and the Swedish Energy Agency, aims to strengthen bilateral cooperation on climate change mitigation, focusing on trading carbon credits to help both nations achieve their emission reduction targets. The carbon market is a market where countries or companies which are still polluting the climate with greenhouse gases finance green projects in countries that reduce carbon emissions. ALSO READ: Rwanda enters tripartite deal to cooperate on Article 6 carbon credit projects The reduced carbon emissions in some countries help to neutralize the emissions that are still being released by climate polluters in other countries. The countries like Rwanda will be selling reduced emissions in terms of carbon credits [one carbon credit is equivalent to one tonne of reduced emissions. The carbon market is part of implementing Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. Paris Agreement was adopted by 196 Parties at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP21) in Paris, France, in December 2015 to keep global warming to 1.5-degree Celcius. Article 6 of the Agreement allows countries to voluntarily cooperate through carbon trading, promoting emission reductions while ensuring environmental integrity. ALSO READ: Will Rwanda’s carbon market take off at UN climate change meeting? The mechanism encourages participation from public and private entities, allowing countries like Rwanda and Sweden to meet their climate pledges by leveraging international resources. By exchanging carbon credits, countries can achieve higher reductions in greenhouse gases than they would by working alone, thus contributing to global climate goals. For Rwanda to achieve goals of Paris Agreement, it seeks $11 billion up to 2030 under climate action plan actions known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) set under the Paris Agreement. Rwanda seeks to reduce 38 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Carbon market is one of the strategies to mobilise such money to achieve this goal. Rwanda expects to sell 7.5 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO2e) – carbon credits – estimating that they could generate $337 million (approx. Rwf420 billion). ALSO READ: Over 3,000 forest farmers set to get incentive under carbon market scheme Given that the minimum price is $30, Rwanda will expect to get $45 per carbon credit (one tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent), hence $337 million from 7.5 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. Financing emissions reduction projects The agreement paves the way for Rwanda and Sweden to develop a bilateral cooperation agreement, under which Sweden will finance various emission reduction projects in Rwanda. These projects will support Rwanda’s green initiatives while also helping Sweden meet its international climate obligations. This partnership sets the foundation for deeper climate-related collaboration, enabling both countries to leverage technical expertise, capacity-building efforts, and joint work plans. It will further Rwanda and Sweden’s efforts to meet their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement. The Paris Agreement allows countries to voluntarily cooperate to meet their mitigation goals by trading carbon credits, thus fostering more effective global emission reductions. This cooperative approach ensures that both countries can achieve greater success in lowering their carbon footprints than they would individually, by combining their efforts and resources. Through this agreement, both nations will participate in dialogue, organize stakeholder meetings, and promote sustainable practices that align with their respective climate goals. Minister of Environment, Valentine Uwamariya said: “This partnership with the Swedish Energy Agency reinforces Rwanda’s commitment to implementing Article 6 of the Paris Agreement and advancing our Nationally Determined Contributions. Rwanda is eager to leverage this partnership to not only meet our climate targets but also foster sustainable development that benefits both our environment and our people.” Martina Fors Mohlin, Chargé d’affaires at the Embassy of Sweden in Kigali, echoed this sentiment, highlighting Rwanda's role as a global example of sustainable development. Rwanda has shown that it is possible to combine economic growth with ambitious climate goals. Through its initiatives for a long-term green transition, Rwanda is an inspiration for other countries. Sweden is committed to financing high-quality Greenhouse Gas mitigation activities in Rwanda that provide substantial contributions to the energy transition in the country, she said.

author: Europa Press Cantabria
title: La huelga general en la logística de Solvay se mantiene tras otra mediación sin acuerdo en el ORECLA
text:
Los sindicatos mantienen el paro indefinido desde el 3 de diciembre y anuncian medidas legales por sustituirse trabajadores en paro por ETTs
SANTANDER, 29 Nov. (EUROPA PRESS) -
La huelga general indefinida convocada en el servicio de logística de Solvay se mantiene desde el próximo martes 3 de diciembre, tras concluir este viernes sin acuerdo una nueva mediación entre los sindicatos y la empresa concesionaria Katoen Natie convocada por el Organismo de Resolución Extrajudicial de Conflictos Laborales (ORECLA).
El comité de empresa de la logística de la fábrica de Barreda (UGT, CCOO y USO) prosigue así con sus movilizaciones, incluidos los paros de dos horas en cada turno de trabajo iniciados este pasado lunes 25 de noviembre y secundados hasta el momento por una media de un 90% de la plantilla de fábrica, según los sindicatos.
El presidente del comité de empresa de Katoen Natie, Lorenzo Fernández (UGT), ha explicado en un comunicado que tras la reunión en el ORECLA, "todo sigue igual porque la empresa no quiere saber nada de respetar nuestros derechos laborales ya adquiridos de anteriores concesionarias, ni de pagarnos los tóxicos y penosos que cobra toda la fábrica menos nosotros ni de proteger la salud y seguridad de la plantilla con un cumplimiento estricto de las normas de prevención de riesgos laborales".
Por eso, la plantilla pasará de los paros de dos horas a la huelga general indefinida a partir del próximo martes, que continuará "hasta cuando sea necesario", ha advertido Fernández.
Además, ha anunciado que el comité de empresa ya ha denunciado a la Inspección de Trabajo, y lo demandará en los tribunales de justicia, que la empresa esté sustituyendo a trabajadores en paro por empleados de empresas de trabajo temporal.
"Es inaceptable e ilegal que se vulnere de un modo tan descarado el derecho constitucional a la huelga y no lo vamos a permitir", ha aseverado el presidente del comité, que ha criticado que, tras casi un mes de movilizaciones, "ni la empresa ni Solvay, que es quien paga, se dan por aludidas".
La huelga general en el servicio de logística de Solvay del 3 de diciembre, que afecta a una plantilla de 73 trabajadores, sucede a las concentraciones de protesta que se iniciaron en la portería de la fábrica de Barreda el 4 de noviembre y los posteriores paros horarios que comenzaron el pasado lunes 25.
Leer más acerca de: Huelga sindicatos

author: @mt
title: Вирус фасоли атакует рак: как растение может спасти тысячи жизней | Health | Seldon News
text: врач в больнице © Designed by Freepik is licensed under Public domain Учёные обнаружили противоопухолевые свойства вируса черноглазой фасоли Он не умеет летать, не светится в темноте и не выглядит героем из фантастического блокбастера. Просто крошечный вирус, который обычно заражает черноглазую фасоль. Но теперь он может стать ключом к лечению рака. Учёные выяснили, что Cowpea Mosaic Virus (CPMV), абсолютно безвредный для человека, вызывает настолько мощный иммунный ответ, что организм начинает атаковать не только его, но и опухолевые клетки. Как это работает? Когда частицы вируса попадают... Copyright information of photo and video materials was taken from the website «MoneyTimes.Ru» , more details in our Terms of Service
